metadata.title: High performance polymeric bipolar plate based on polypropylene/graphite/graphene/nano-carbon black composites for PEM fuel cells

sections.text:
lable at ScienceDirect
Contents lists avai
Renewable Energy
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate/renene
High performance polymeric bipolar plate based on polypropylene/ graphite/graphene/nano-carbon black composites for PEM fuel cells
Ali Adloo, Morteza Sadeghi*, Mahmood Masoomi, Hadi Najafi Pazhooh Department of Chemical Engineering, Isfahan University of Technology, Isfahan 84156-83111, Iran
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 9 January 2016 Received in revised form 10 June 2016 Accepted 24 July 2016
Keywords: Bipolar plates High structure nano carbon black Graphene Maleic anhydride grafted polypropylene Electrical conductivity
* Corresponding author. Tel.: þ98 31 33915645; fax E-mail address: m-Sadeghi@cc.iut.ac.ir (M. Sadegh
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.renene.2016.07.062 0960-1481/© 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t
In the present study, the effect of the addition of electrically conductive additives such as graphite, graphene, and high structure nano-carbon black on the manufacturing of polypropylene bipolar plates was studied. Furthermore, for achieving better dispersion of graphene in the matrix, maleic anhydride grafted polypropylene, as a compatibilizer, was utilized. An internal mixing device was used in order to mix additives with polypropylene matrix. Additionally, molding procedure was performed via the compression molding method. In-plane electrical conductivity as well as the flexural strength of various compositions were studied. The best composition of such composites possessed the electrical conductivity of 104.63 S/cm and flexural strength of 44.28 MPa. These values are higher than those designated by the United States Department of Energy for construction of bipolar plates.
© 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Bipolar plate (BP) is an important part of fuel cells. The desired long-term operations of fuel cells could be attained by employing proper components especially BPs. BPs plays pivotal roles in gas and water managements, electrical performance, and mechanical stability of fuel cells. BPs have to possess desirable properties including mechanical strength, thermal and electrical conductivity, gas impermeability, low density, and corrosion resistance [1e5].
A group ofmaterials as proper candidates for construction of BPs exists. Pure graphite is a known material used in BPs due to its suitable thermal and electrical conductivity, corrosion resistance, and low density [1,2]. Moreover, different kinds of metals andmetal alloys such as stainless steel, aluminum, nickel, copper, titanium, bulk amorphous alloys, and even carbon steel have been used as BP materials [6e8].
Recently, composite materials based on polymeric matrices and graphite have been replaced instead of pure graphite and metals as BP material [9]. BPs composite have some advantages over metallic materials with regard to possessing some outstanding features including acceptable corrosion resistance and low weight [10]. Polymer-based composite materials could be produced in several
: þ98 31 33912677. i).
available manufacturing processes e.g., preform molding, injection or compression molding, two-component injection molding and wet-lay lamination method [1,11]. Despite these advantages, some disadvantages such as low electrical conductivity, mechanical properties, and high gas permeability should be considered for composite BPs [2,9,12e15]. Either thermoplastic or thermoset matrices could generally be used to manufacture BPs composites [16e18]. There are several different types of thermoplastic matrices being available, such as polypropylene (PP) [19,20], polyphenylene sulfide (PPS) [21,22], and polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) [15]for production of BPs composite. Polypropylene composites reinforcing with fillers offer goodmechanical properties as well as easy and cost-effective processing. In general, filler used in composites has to be dispersed well in order to achieve optimal properties. Since polypropylene has no polar functional groups in its backbone, dispersion of graphite into this polymer matrix is difficult and such poor dispersion leads to a low electrical conductivity [23]. In order to overcome this issue, modification of polypropylene could be accomplished through grafting of polymer with polar molecules such as maleic anhydride (MAH) [24e27].
Generally, improvement of electrical properties could be attained via the incorporation of other types of carbon-based fillers alongside conventional graphite in the polymer matrix [28,29]. In other words, several types of carbonaceous fillers such as carbon black, carbon fibers, multi-walled and single-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNT and SWCNT), carbon nanofibers and expanded
graphite also could be considered as modifiers in composites to improve mechanical and electrical properties [28e36]. It was reported that the enhancement of electrical conductivity was obtained by employing a combination of graphite and carbon black in matrix [31]. Carbon black particles could act as bridges between graphite particles mostly due to their smaller size resulting in better conductivity [37]. Application of pp-MAH and graphene to enhance both the electrical conductivity andmechanical properties of polypropylene-based BPs has been also reported in the literature [25,38e40].
In this study, the effects of graphene plates addition on the electrical conductivity and flexural strength of polypropylene bipolar plates filled with both graphite and high structure nano carbon black was investigated. Furthermore, amount of filler used in these composites was optimized in order to reach finest level of properties. Compared with thermoset materials, a thermoplastic polymer, polypropylene, was chosen as matrix due to the fact that such polymer possesses superior flexural strength being higher than that of thermoset polymer. In addition to this, compared with other thermoplastics used in bipolar plates including polyvinylidene fluoride and Polyphenylene sulfide, polypropylene is cheaper and available. Once composites were manufactured, the effect of filler addition such as HSNCB, graphene and presence of maleic anhydride grafted polypropylene on both mechanical and electrical properties was investigated.

sections.heading: 2.1. Raw materials
sections.text: Graphite powder (with an average size of particles 45 mm), hydrazine hydrate (85% purity), and sodium nitrate (NaNO3) were obtained from Merck, Germany. Sulfuric acid (H2SO4), potassium permanganate (KMNO4), hydrochloric acid (HCl), and hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) were obtained from Mojalali Co., Tehran, Iran. The polypropylene homopolymer was purchased from Arak Petrochemical Co., Arak, Iran, with MFI ¼ 6 Dg/min. maleic anhydride grafted polypropylene (pp-MAH) with 1 wt% grafted MAH was bought from Kimia Javid Sepahan Co., Isfahan, Iran. The nano size EC300J type, high structure nano carbon black (HSNCB), with an average particle size of 10e20 nmwas purchased from Akzo Nobel Co., China.

sections.heading: 2.2. Preparation of graphite oxide
sections.text: Graphite oxidewas prepared via Hummer's method [41]. Briefly, 2 g of graphite powder were dispersed in 46 ml of concentrated H2SO4(98%) into a flask in an ice bath. Then 1 g of NaNO3 and 6 g KMnO4, were added to the mixture (reaction temperature should not exceed 20 C). Themixturewas stirred about 2 h, at which point its temperature reached 35 C and was maintained for 30min. Then 92 ml of water was slowly added to the mixture, causing the temperature to reach 95 C. The system was maintained at this temperature until termination of the reaction after 30min was carried out. Finally, the brown cake was separated with a Buchner filter and washed with 3% H2O2 and 5% HCl (37%). The resulted graphite oxide was dried for 12 h in vacuum oven at 70 C.

sections.heading: 2.3. Graphene preparation
sections.text:
0.3 g of graphite oxide was added to 300 ml water in a roundbottom flask. A Hielscher ultrasonic homogenizer (UP200S, 180 w, Heilscher Ultrasonics GmbH, Germany) was used for 90min in order to disperse graphite oxide in solution. The unit weight ratio of hydrazine/graphite oxide was adjusted to be 1 and the suspension
was heated to 95 C for 12 h. Finally, the graphene powder was washed with distillated water and methanol frequently.

sections.heading: 2.4. Preparation of graphene/polypropylene composite
sections.text: Depending on the wt% of HSNCB and pp-MAH, detailed formulations are listed in Table 1. Graphene was also added to one of the combinations to compare with the best base. We chose three different combinations of graphene. Due to the aggregation of graphene sheets, we used pp-MAH as a compatibilizer to improve graphene dispersion. BPs were made with melt mixing by using an internal mixer with a rotation speed of 100 rpm at 180 C for 15min. The composite were molded with hot press at 180 C for 10min under 10 MPa into sheets with a thickness of 4 mm.

sections.heading: 2.5. Characterization
sections.text:
ATR-FTIR spectra of the powders were recorded between 500 and 4000 cm 1, Tensor 27 Bruker FTIR spectrometer (Germany). The powders were mixed onto the KBr pellet, and then dried about 15min to remove moisture. X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed with Philips X0 Pert-MPD using Cu K a radiation (l¼ 1.54 Å.Generator tensionwas 40 kV and generator current was 30 mA. Scans were taken from 0 to 60 , and the scan rate was chosen at 5 min 1).
Atomic force microscopy (AFM, DME 95-200-E, Danish Micro Engineering A/S,Denmark) was used to study the nanostructure of the graphene oxide. Samples for AFM imaging were prepared by depositing colloidal suspensions of graphite oxide on lab lamella. Concentration of colloid suspensions was chosen to be 0.03 g in 300 cc water. Water bath sonication was performed with a 180 W Hielscher UP400S sonicator (Germany). All images were collected under ambient conditions at 30% relative humidity and 25 Cwith a raster scanning rate of 1 Hz.
The morphology of the surface fracture of composite samples obtained from flexural test were characterized by scanning electron microscope (KYKY-EM3200 SEM, China) with sputter coating of a layer of gold with thickness of 100 Å. Three-point bending tests were carried out on samples with dimension of 2 cm 8 cm 4 mm using the Hounsfield universal testing machine (Tinius Olsen Ltd., UK), according to ASTM D790-02. The support span was 6.4 cm, and the cross-head speed was 1.27 mm/ min 1. Flexural strength was calculated according to the following equation:
Flexural strength ¼ 3FL 2Wt2
(1)
where F is the breaking force of the samples, L is the support span, W is the width, and t is the thickness of the sample. Electrical conductivity of the composite plates was measured using the fourpoint probe method according to the ASTM D991-89 procedure. A programmable Keithley 2400 Series Source Meter (USA) was used to apply the current (10 mA) and the voltage drop was measured using a Keithley 2182A nanovoltmeter (USA). The averaged value among 5 readings for each sample was reported as the conductivity of the composite. Resistivity (r) and conductivity (s) were calculated as follows:
r ¼ RWDK/L (2)
s ¼ 1/r (3)
where W, D, and L are the width, thickness and distance between voltage electrodes, respectively, and K is the constant, it equals to
0.001.

sections.heading: 3.1.1. ATR-FTIR analysis
sections.text: ATR-FTIR studies have been performed to investigate the functional groups of graphene sheets during the synthesis procedure. FTIR spectra of graphite, graphite oxide, and synthesized graphene are represented in Fig. 1. Two peaks at 2906 cm 1 and 1564 cm 1 are characteristic of CeH bond and stretching of CeC double bond, respectively (Fig. 1a). After performing the oxidation process, the stretching peak of CeO bonds at 1056 cm 1, 1166 cm 1, and 1427 cm 1 represent the hydroxyl, epoxy, and carboxyl groups, correspondingly. In addition, the peak at 1647 cm 1 is attributed to the adsorbed molecules and the skeletal vibration of non-oxidized parts [42]. The stretching of carbonyl groups at 1728 cm 1 and the stretching of OeH groups in the range of 3100e3600 cm 1 are obvious in Fig. 1b [43e46]. The spectrum at Fig. 1c was taken after reduction with hydrazine Hydrate. It is clear that all of the functional groups except hydroxyl groups (1002 cm 1) had been reduced to CeC double bonds (1558 cm 1) [47].

sections.heading: 3.1.2. X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis
sections.text:
XRD analysis has been employed to examine the distance between the synthesized graphene layers. As illustrated in Fig. 2a, the main peak of graphite (002) was obtained at a 2q value of 26.5 , which indicates an interlayer distance of 3.35 Å. After oxidation, according to the low intense and broadened peak of graphite oxide at 2q value of 10.4 (Fig. 2b), the interlayer distance has to increase to a value of 8.48 Å. In comparison to graphite (Fig. 2a), the reduced graphite oxide showed a broader and less intense peak at higher 2q values in spectrum. Considering a and c spectra for graphite and graphene, the peak appeared at lower 2q values, around 21 ,
corresponding to the interlayer distance of 4.15 Å. The low intensity of the peak, in comparison to graphite, could be attributed to breakage of bonds between the sheets. The broadened peak in XRD spectra (Fig. 2c) could be attributed to the incomplete separation of graphite sheets [48,49]. Conclusively, by oxidation of graphite, the distance between layers has increased. Toward the reduction of graphite oxide, the distance between layers of graphene was diminished, but it was still larger than that of pure graphite. Conclusively, by increasing interlayer distance, better intercalation of polymer between graphene layers could be expected.

sections.heading: 3.1.3. Atomic force microscopy (AFM) analysis
sections.text: In this study, AFM analyses show the delamination of graphite layers and thickness of each layer, Fig. 3a and b are representative of AFM images of graphite oxide. Most of the layers are 1 nm thick. For precise determination of the thickness of layers, the results of analyses of two points in Fig. 3 have been represented in Fig. 3c. It is obvious that most graphite oxide sheets are mono layers with a thickness of 0.8 nm. Fig. 3 shows that mono and double layers can be achieved by chemical reduction. It has been also concluded that the existence of thicker layers resulting from chemical reduction on the surface of these layers leads to decrement in the layers' distances. Ultrasound cannot reach between these packed layers. It is obvious that most of the layers have a thickness of less than 1 nm [50].

sections.heading: 3.2. Effect of applying polypropylene graft maleic anhydride (ppMAH) on the characteristics of bipolar plates
sections.text:
In the present work, the HSNCB particles were added to the graphite-polypropylene composite to improve conductivity. Grafting polypropylenewithmaleic anhydride (MAH) was accomplished for the purpose of increasing the compatibility of fillers with polymer matrix; therefore, more favorable electrical conductivity
and mechanical strength were expected. The addition of 5 wt% of pp-MAH to the composite lowers the surface energies between polymer matrix with additive (better coverage of fillers) at the lower composition percentages [25,51e53]. As shown in Table 1, the increment in the amount of high structure carbon at constant value of pp-MAH causes the electrical conductivity increase due to a decrease in the thickness of the coated layer of polypropylene on the particles. This reduction of thickness could enhance the jumping of the electrons between carbon particles. As represented in Table 2, by increasing the amount of pp-MAH to 10 wt% for the composite containing 7 wt% of HSNCB, a decrease in composite electrical conductivity was observed. This could be attributed to the high shielding of HSNCB particles by the polypropylene matrix. As represented in Table 2, with an increase in the weight percent of pp-MAH for the composite containing 7 wt% HSNCB, a decrease in flexural strength has been observed. Its explanation may be related to the lowermolecular weight of pp-MAH and the presence of more free ends in polymer, which causes more voids to be formed in the whole structure.
The SEM micrographs in Fig. 4 showed more coverage of additives via the addition of pp-MAH in the composite. This is due to the decrease in surface energies between the matrix and particles. In addition, flexural strength was reduced by the addition of pp-MAH,
because pp-MAH has a lower molecular weight than polypropylene, and higher amount of free ends in polymer, which leads to more voids in the whole structure. Therefore, the amount of ppMAH should reach an optimum value in polymer to optimize electrical conductivity and flexural strength. Consequently, the 5wt % of pp-MAH is the optimized value in comparison to the 10 wt%, and improvement of mechanical and electrical properties have been obtained at 5 wt%.

sections.heading: 3.3. Effect of applying high structure nano carbon black (HSNCB) on the characteristics of bipolar plates
sections.text:
To increase the electrical conductivity and flexural strength of the binary composite, HSNCBwas added to composition to increase the electrical conductivity and flexural strength of the composite [54]. Because of the low aspect ratio of graphite, it could be used only for improvement of electrical conductivity. However it could not increase flexural strength. As depicted in Table 1, at 5 wt % of pp-MAH, the addition of HSNCB increase electrical conductivity due to electrons move to other conductive fillers easily. As presented in Table 1, the electrical conductivity of composite with 7 wt % weight percentage of HSNCB exhibits 7-times greater conductivity in comparison to the 6 wt% weight percentage, which
g 5and 10 wt% of polypropylene-MAH.
indicates the percolation threshold for this composite. The addition of HSNCB above a value of 7 wt% causesmore paths to be formed for electron conductivity resulting in higher electrical conductivity. Furthermore, because of the small sizes of HSNCB particles, in comparison to those of graphite, the HSNCB particles could act as a conductive bridge among graphite particles. Adding contents of filler with weight percent above 7 wt% can cause some problems, such as filler-polypropylene wet ability and some processing difficulties.
In the SEM images of Fig. 5, graphite particles are more efficiently converted to thinner layers during the polymer process in the samples containing both fillers. As shown in the micrographs, the layers of graphite structures cannot be illustrate directly by SEM analyses. However, the particles are shown as spheres in this figure. Delamination of graphite is mostly evaluated by XRD and cannot be shown by SEM images. Graphite delamination can be concluded from the uniform structure of the broken surface in SEM micrographs, which show no aggregation of graphite in the matrix (Fig. 5a). Additionally, the layered graphite structure in Fig. 5a could be attributed to delamination due to structural shear. More paths for electron transfer could result from the junction of HSNCB particles to the basal planes of graphite [55].
Furthermore, the graphite particles are surrounded by small HSNCB particles (Fig. 5b); therefore, the reduction in nonconductive sites in composite could be expected. Moreover, some voids appeared in the broken surface in Fig. 5b. This is due to aggregation of the graphite in the matrix. Such aggregation leads to a decrease in the electrical conductivity of the media.
The flexural strength studies on HSNCB-containing samples are represented in Table 1. It shows the gradual increase in flexural strength to the value of 6 wt% of HSNCB, as well as the gradual decrease above this value. The high covering ability of polymer matrix is necessary for the higher weight percentages of HSNCB. Consequently, when the sample is subjected to this tension, the
capability for bearing stress is decreasing and the fracture at the interface of HSNCB and polypropylene matrix is expected. The HSNCB particles play the role of stress concentration points. The pp-MAH shows greater tendencies toward the graphene particles than the HSNCB particles due to the presence of CeO groups. One of the most important causes of the easier type of fracture in graphene-free samples could be attributed to the weaker contact between graphite and pp-MAH [23,53].

sections.heading: 3.4. Effect of applying graphene sheets on the characteristics of bipolar plates
sections.text:
Optical microscopy analysis was utilized to study the dispersion of graphene particles with the application of pp-MAH in composite (Fig. 6). The results also have been analyzed by Image-Pro Software (Media Cybernetics, Inc., USA) and the two samples in Table 3 with certain compositions have been studied. Results are displayed in Tables 4 and 5 for both samples, showing outcomes at the both single and cluster levels for the two samples. For cluster, a maximum value of 70.087 mm in length and 46.861 mm in width have been converted to 29.791 mm in length and 24.483 mm in width, and this is due to the addition of pp-MAH. It should be noted that “clusters” refer to agglomerate particles and “singles” refers to particles that is separated from each other.
Results indicate that the addition of pp-MAH decreases the maximum size of the cluster in sample 2, and an increase in the dispersion of graphene particles has been observed. Due to the absence of polar groups in polypropylene and because of its long organic chains, polypropylene interaction with graphene particles vis- a-vis factors such as hydrogen bonding is weak. Consequently, the dispersion of graphene particles could be improved by using pp-MAH as a compatibilizer. According to the Image-Pro results and the optical microscope images, having applied pp-MAH as compatibilizing agent, better dispersion of aggregated particles has
been obtained. The results of conductivity studies for ternary components containing graphene samples are represented in Table 6. Addition of 1 wt% of graphene could dramatically double the electrical conductivity in comparison to a sample which does not contain graphene. The improvement of conductivity could be interpreted by the better dispersion of graphene particles due to the effective interactions between hydroxyl groups of graphene and pp-MAH. Lower conductivity was obtained for the composition containing 2 wt% graphene. This could be explained via the aggregation of graphene particles with high surface energy [52]. Additionally, the remaining functional groups such as CeO on graphene particles after the reduction as well as the defect sites could be causes for the lower electrical conductivity in the higher percentage compositions of graphene [56].
The SEM images of the sample in Fig. 5 were taken after the flexural strength test. This could offer more electron percolating paths through the composite. Additionally, given the planar structure of graphene sheets and their orientations during the molding process (Fig. 5c), higher plane conductivity is expected. Finally, the improved adhesion between the polymer matrix and the filler particles was achieved via the addition of pp-MAH to the composite. The holes in Fig. 5d could be attributed to the exclusion of graphene or graphite aggregates.
Table 6 demonstrates that the samples containing graphene with the 5 wt% of HSNCB and the addition of graphene to the weight percentage of 1% could cause an increase in flexural strength. The increase in graphene weight percentage to 2% surprisingly diminished flexural strength. This reduction in mechanical properties such as flexural strength in composites could be related to the aggregation of nano fillers due to their high surface energies [25,57,58].

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
In this study, the optimum amount of fillers for using in polymer bipolar plate is achieved it is hypothesized that such procedure was cost-effective, compared with other literature reported for DOE target. Effects of different additives in binary and ternary system on electrical conductivity and flexural strength properties of BPs (as two important parameters) have been studied. Results have demonstrated that the addition of carbon particles with high structure and small sizes causes major influences on electrical conductivity. The percolation threshold of BPs occurs at lower values. The application of pp-MAH at a certain composition can cause higher dispersion of graphene into the polymermatrix due to the decrease in surface energies at boundaries. The increment in content of graphene above a certain value leads to a reduction in electrical conductivity, due to the possibility of agglomeration of graphene particles. The weaker dispersion of the graphene in matrix could result in paths for electron conductivity formed fewer. By comparing binary and ternary system shows that at low percentage of graphene, even with structured and conductive network,
deteriorates conductivity and it reaches the value equaling to the value of HSNCB. The new method dispersion and resolved structural defects of graphene could increase electrical conductivity more than that of HSNCB. The improvement in flexural strength of some samples with certain compositions of graphene and pp-MAH could be attributed to the formation of hydrogen bonds. By the addition of HSNCB percentage in composites, electrical conductivity and flexural strength have increased in most samples. The increment in the value of pp-MAH in prepared samples leads to a decrement in electrical conductivity and flexural strength.

metadata.abstractText: In the present study, the effect of the addition of electrically conductive additives such as graphite, graphene, and high structure nano-carbon black on the manufacturing of polypropylene bipolar plates was studied. Furthermore, for achieving better dispersion of graphene in the matrix, maleic anhydride grafted polypropylene, as a compatibilizer, was utilized. An internal mixing device was used in order to mix additives with polypropylene matrix. Additionally, molding procedure was performed via the compression molding method. In-plane electrical conductivity as well as the flexural strength of various compositions were studied. The best composition of such composites possessed the electrical conductivity of 104.63 S/cm and flexural strength of 44.28 MPa. These values are higher than those designated by the United States Department of Energy for construction of bipolar plates. © 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
